_**Anne with an E**_ is a Canadian [drama](/wiki/Drama_\(film_and_television\)
"Drama \(film and television\)") television series based on the 1908 novel
_[Anne of Green Gables](/wiki/Anne_of_Green_Gables "Anne of Green Gables")_ by
[Lucy Maud Montgomery](/wiki/Lucy_Maud_Montgomery "Lucy Maud Montgomery"), and
adapted by [Emmy Award](/wiki/Emmy_Award "Emmy Award")-winning writer and
producer [Moira Walley-Beckett](/wiki/Moira_Walley-Beckett "Moira Walley-
Beckett").[1] It airs on [CBC Television](/wiki/CBC_Television "CBC
Television") in Canada, and elsewhere in the world it is available for
streaming on Netflix.[2] The first season consists of seven episodes, with
[Niki Caro](/wiki/Niki_Caro "Niki Caro") directing the 90-minute season
premiere.[3] The series premiered on March 19, 2017, on CBC, the first season
finale airing on April 30, 2017.[4] The first season was titled simply
_**Anne**_ in Canada, while Netflix used _Anne with an E_.[5] CBC adopted the
_Anne with an E_ name beginning in the second season.[6]

On August 3, 2017, both CBC and Netflix renewed the series for a 10-episode
second season,[7] which began production in November 2017.[8] Season 2
premiered on Netflix on July 6, 2018, and on CBC on September 23, 2018.[9][10]

In August 2018, CBC and Netflix renewed the series for a 10-episode third
season to premiere in 2019.[11]

## Premise[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Premise")]

In the late 19th century, brother and sister Matthew and Marilla Cuthbert,
both in their old age, decide to take on an orphan boy to help out around
their ancestral farm of [Green
Gables](/wiki/Green_Gables_\(Prince_Edward_Island\) "Green Gables \(Prince
Edward Island\)"), on the outskirts of the town of
[Avonlea](/wiki/Avonlea_\(Anne_of_Green_Gables\) "Avonlea \(Anne of Green
Gables\)"), on [Prince Edward Island](/wiki/Prince_Edward_Island "Prince
Edward Island"). When Matthew goes to pick the child up at the railway
station, he finds not a boy, but a high-spirited and talkative girl, [Anne
Shirley](/wiki/Anne_Shirley "Anne Shirley"). At first, the Cuthberts are
inclined to send her back, particularly after Marilla's [brooch](/wiki/Brooch
"Brooch") goes missing, and Anne, in despair, runs away. The family reconciles
and Anne settles in her new home. Upon starting school, Anne once again
displays boundless enthusiasm which is nevertheless easily turned into despair
when things go wrong, which they often do. Slowly, her ebullient nature wins
over those around her.

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Production")]

The production companies are listed as Northwood Anne, Northwood Entertainment
and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation; Netflix is only the distributor.[16]
The executive producers are [Miranda de Pencier](/wiki/Miranda_de_Pencier
"Miranda de Pencier") and series creator [Moira Walley-
Beckett](/wiki/Moira_Walley-Beckett "Moira Walley-Beckett").

According to de Pencier, the adaptation of the novel for this television
series was intended to provide a different look and feel compared to past
productions; they were aiming for a "documentary level of realism", as
reflected in the extraordinary detail which has gone into the design of sets
and costumes.[17]

Production on Season 3 was planned to start in late 2018[18]

### Personnel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Personnel")]

Besides the show itself having a larger number of female characters than male,
women serving as executive producer and showrunner, the series has several
female directors.[19] For the second season, showrunner and scriptwriter Moira
Walley-Beckett was joined by a team of women writers.[20] Season 3 will also
feature a team of women writers.[21]

### Casting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Casting")]

Approximately 1800 girls on three continents auditioned for the role of [Anne
Shirley](/wiki/Anne_Shirley "Anne Shirley"). Amybeth McNulty was chosen for
her ability to deliver dialogue which is "incredibly thick and dynamic and
beautiful", according to Miranda de Pencier. Walley-Beckett describes her as
at once "luminous," transparent, smart, soulful and emotional.[19]

### Filming
locations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Filming locations")]

The series has occasionally filmed on [Prince Edward
Island](/wiki/Prince_Edward_Island "Prince Edward Island") but, for budgetary
reasons, it has primarily been filmed in [Southern
Ontario](/wiki/Southern_Ontario "Southern Ontario"), at a Toronto studio, at
outdoor locations in or near Toronto including [Black Creek Pioneer
Village](/wiki/Black_Creek_Pioneer_Village "Black Creek Pioneer Village"), in
Waterloo Region at locations including [Doon Pioneer
Village](/wiki/Doon_Pioneer_Village "Doon Pioneer Village"), and in
communities such as [Millbrook](/wiki/Millbrook,_Ontario "Millbrook,
Ontario"), [Pickering](/wiki/Pickering,_Ontario "Pickering, Ontario"),
[Hamilton](/wiki/Hamilton,_Ontario "Hamilton, Ontario"), and
[Caledon](/wiki/Caledon,_Ontario "Caledon, Ontario").[22][23][24][25]

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Music")]

The opening theme is the song "[Ahead by a Century](/wiki/Ahead_by_a_Century
"Ahead by a Century")" performed and originally composed by Canadian band [The
Tragically Hip](/wiki/The_Tragically_Hip "The Tragically Hip").[19]

## Themes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Themes")]

Moira Walley-Beckett had this to say about her treatment, which is darker than
the previous productions: "In this day and age, themes of identity, prejudice,
bullying, being an outsider, searching for a way to be accepted and how to
belong are entirely topical and super relevant, and those are themes that are
built into the story of 'Anne.'" She went on to call Anne Shirley an
"accidental [feminist](/wiki/Feminist "Feminist")", and how she "really wanted
to tell this story now."[19] For the second season, according to what she
called her "master plan", Walley-Beckett introduced an entirely new character
of her own, Bash,[15] to reflect the
[racial](/wiki/Race_\(human_categorization\) "Race \(human categorization\)")
[diversity](/wiki/Multiculturalism "Multiculturalism") present in and around
[Charlottetown](/wiki/Charlottetown "Charlottetown") at the time of the novel,
with a view to representing a community absent from previous adaptations,
achieving this by having Gilbert travel on a steamship and meet with the new
character in [Trinidad](/wiki/Trinidad "Trinidad"): "Bash is the vehicle to
explore intolerance and inequality, even more when he goes to The Bog, when he
learns that other black people live there."[26] Walley-Beckett explained: "The
Bog is the community that's just outside of Charlottetown, where people of
color were marginalized and had their own community there."

The plan for Season 3 was to cover topics such as identity, feminism, bullying
and gender parity.[18] Walley-Beckett provided this additional hint: "Our
beloved Anne will be 16 years old when we return to this season full of
romantic complications, bold adventures and dramatic discoveries. I will
explore important, contemporary themes that I hope will continue to resonate
with, and inspire and uplift, our audience."[21]

## Broadcast and
release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Broadcast and release")]

The series initially premiered on March 19, 2017, on CBC and aired on a weekly
basis, the season finale airing on April 30, 2017.

The series debuted on Netflix on May 12, 2017, under the title _Anne With An
E_.[5][27] The second and later seasons were retitled to match Netflix's title
by the CBC which had initially used the title _Anne_.[28] The CBC premier for
Season 2 was in late September, after it had been streaming on Netflix for
some time.

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Anne_with_an_E&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Critical response")]

The first season has achieved a rating of 84% on [Rotten
Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes"), the site's critical
consensus stating: "_Anne with an E_ uses its complex central character to
offer a boldly stylish, emotionally resonant spin on classic source material
that satisfies in its own right."[34] The series has received a rating of 79
on [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") based on fifteen reviews,
indicating "generally favorable reviews".[35]

Emily Ashby, writing for [Common Sense Media](/wiki/Common_Sense_Media "Common
Sense Media"), calls the series an "exceptional" and "spectacular"
interpretation, giving it four out of five stars.[36] Tasha Cerny, contributor
for the Tracking Board, praises the cinematography as lush and colourful, the
characters vibrant, and the plot "surprisingly thrilling for a story about a
young girl living in a small secluded community in the late nineteenth
century. I laughed, I cried, and I didn't expect either from a show about a
little girl."[37] Gwen Inhat of _[The A.V. Club](/wiki/The_A.V._Club "The A.V.
Club")_ calls the series "at once darker and sweeter than the original" novel,
praising the core cast, reserving the highest for the series lead: "Amybeth
McNulty defies her youth with a performance that's less a portrayal of Anne
than an absolute possession. It can't be easy to make Anne's fanciful language
sing the way she does, and McNulty captures the endearing awkwardness that
enables Anne to win over everyone she comes in contact with."[38] Writing of
the 90-minute premiere episode for the _[Toronto Star](/wiki/Toronto_Star
"Toronto Star")_ , [Johanna Schneller](/wiki/Johanna_Schneller "Johanna
Schneller") was appreciative of Walley-Beckett's departures from the novel,
bringing its [subtext](/wiki/Subtext "Subtext") to the fore: "Reading between
the novel's lines and adding [verisimilitude](/wiki/Verisimilitude
"Verisimilitude"), she gives us quick but potent glimpses of the miseries many
orphans faced in 1890s imperialist culture."[39] Hanh Nguyen, reviewing the
series for [IndieWire](/wiki/IndieWire "IndieWire"), concurs with this
assessment, saying: "Rather than ruining the series, they give the context for
why Anne would be filled with gratitude for the beauties of nature, basic
human decency and having a family to call her own. Montgomery had based much
of Anne's need for escape into imagination on her own lonely childhood, and
her stories have always had an underlying poignancy that made them all the
sweeter."[40] Jen Chaney, writing for
[Vulture.com](/wiki/New_York_Magazine#Digital_expansion_and_blogs "New York
Magazine"), agrees, saying: "What distinguishes it from other previous Anne
iterations is its willingness to harden some of the story's softness, just
enough, to create an element of realism that period pieces, Gables-related or
not, can be inclined to avoid."[41] [Neil Genzlinger](/wiki/Neil_Genzlinger
"Neil Genzlinger") writing for _[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times
"The New York Times")_ , commenting on reports of darkness and grittiness,
goes so far as to call the adaptation "richer" than the source material: "Ms.
McNulty's Anne is still wonderfully ebullient and eminently likable; she's
just not the one-dimensional figure of other adaptations".[42] Annie
Hirschlag, writing for [Mic](/wiki/Mic_\(media_company\) "Mic \(media
company\)"), suggests that a genuinely contemporary _Anne_ is bound to reflect
the current television landscape and wider culture of its times (the 2010s):
"Since today's entertainment is peppered with antiheroes — characters who are
far from perfect, even occasionally villainous — it makes sense that Anne's
familiar idealism is fringed with darkness and agony."[43]

Some reviewers were more ambivalent, mainly about Walley-Beckett's changes to
the story. Canadian novelist [Saleema Nawaz](/wiki/Saleema_Nawaz "Saleema
Nawaz"), who reviewed the 90-minute first episode for _[Toronto
Life](/wiki/Toronto_Life "Toronto Life")_ , said she enjoyed it more than she
expected, particularly the set designs and costumes, as well as the
performances by McNulty and Thomson, and she approved of the choice of theme
song as reflective of the continued relevance of the source material. She was
less sure about how far the series intended to stray from that source
material, and disapproved of the "manufactured drama, such as Matthew's wild
horse ride".[44] Writing for _[Entertainment
Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ , Isabella
Beidenharn expressed similar feelings, but, "putting the source material
aside, it's a fine show on its own", and she conceded that "inventing a dark
side might help _Anne With an E_ fit into today's TV landscape".[45] Allison
Keene, writing for [Collider](/wiki/Collider_\(website\) "Collider
\(website\)"), agrees that _Anne_ is a good drama on its own terms, but allows
it is "only a fair adaptation" of the novel, at its best in the home scenes:
"_Anne with an E_ is undeniably the most stylish adaptation we've ever seen of
_Anne of Green Gables_. But its desire to reveal more of Anne's miserable past
in order to be more true to what the desperation of an orphan is like feels at
odds with Montgomery's story."[46] Writing for
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ , critic Sonia
Saraiya is even more ambivalent, describing the series as on the one hand "a
brilliant adaptation" which "succeeds admirably", but on the other hand, "the
show can't quite sustain the brilliance, veering first into maudlin territory
and then into the oddly saccharine as it tests out its tone", contending that
"the show gets a bit bogged down in telling the story of Anne's dysfunction",
presenting "a slightly soapy view of Anne's trials and tribulations that at
times really humanize her and in others, are rather infantilizing".[47]

Sarah Larson, writing for _[The New Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New
Yorker")_ , was not at all impressed with changes made to the story, arguing
that they alter Anne's character to the point of non-recognition. While she
acknowledges that bringing subtext to the fore is a fine idea, she is not
pleased with the execution, saying that the result is part "the Anne we know
and love" and part "untrustworthy stranger", calling the alteration and
addition of scenes a "betrayal" of Montgomery's novel, comparing the treatment
unfavourably to [Patricia Rozema](/wiki/Patricia_Rozema "Patricia Rozema")'s
[1999 adaptation](/wiki/Mansfield_Park_\(film\) "Mansfield Park \(film\)") of
[Jane Austen](/wiki/Jane_Austen "Jane Austen")'s _[Mansfield
Park](/wiki/Mansfield_Park "Mansfield Park")_.[48] For Joanna Robinson,
writing for _[Vanity Fair](/wiki/Vanity_Fair_magazine "Vanity Fair magazine")_
, a central problem with the show is that it "seems to think that in order for
Anne to be a feminist figure, she has to butt up against a straw-man-filled
patriarchy," and so it turned many of the male characters into
[misogynists](/wiki/Misogynists "Misogynists"), most notably the Reverend
Allan, who is considered by Anne to be a "kindred spirit" in the book: "_Anne
with an E_ seems to think Anne's triumphs are only noteworthy if she's
continually told she can't succeed, when in fact her unfettered brilliance
needs no such clumsy opposition. It also seems to think that Anne needs a
radical feminist makeover when, in fact, the story of her success was feminist
in its own right." This is part of a more general problem Robinson notes, that
conflicts are exaggerated and overdone: "this series thrives on non-stop
tragedy."[49]
